Description: Terracotta amulet-mould in Nile clay; impression of a simplified version of wedjat eye inscribed in a rectangle; outer edge of impression is oval; would have formed right eye when moulded; two deep grooves marked through edge of mould down to level of bottom of impression, so the amulet produced from this mould would be pierced lengthwise; in grey brown micaceous Nile silt fabric.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Scarab Factory (noted in Petrie's plate)
Curator's comments: In addition to glazed composition scarabs and scaraboids, the ‘Scarab Factory’ at Naukratis was also producing amulets (on the various productions from the Scarab Factory see Webb, forthcoming; see also Gorton 1996, 177-180, fig. 35). Petrie listed a number of amulet-moulds including moulds for wedjat eyes of different types (Petrie 1886, 37, pl. XXXVIII, 16-17). This specimen comes probably from the Scarab Factory, though it is crudely modelled in a grey-brown clay which is different from that of the majority of the scarab and amulet moulds from Naukratis. Workmanship is also crude. So should be careful about its origin and date. For a rather similar type of mould: BM 1888,0601.748. Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884-5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for dating, in R. Thomas (ed.), The Naukratis workshop, held at the British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVIII, no. 17) (almost identical cast from such mould)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OJ.01) (phase 2)
